title: Data Analysis and Visualization in R
text:
1 Course description
In today’s data-driven era, mastering data visualization is essential. This course equips you with practical skills to transform raw data into meaningful visual stories that drive understanding and decision-making. Whether you’re a data enthusiast or a professional looking to enhance your visualization prowess, this course offers invaluable insights and hands-on practice.


2 Learning Objectives:
By the end of this course, participants will:

Identify appropriate visualization types for different datasets and audiences.
Prepare data through cleaning, exploration, and formatting using R.
Create impactful, accessible, and visually appealing visualizations using ggplot2 and its extensions.
Develop proficiency in coding from scratch for data visualization tasks.



3 Course Highlights:

Understanding Data Visualization: Learn to identify the most suitable visualization types for your data and audience.
Data Preparation: Master techniques to clean, explore, and format data for visualization using R.
Building Visualizations: Utilize R, including ggplot2 and its extensions, to craft impactful and visually engaging charts.
Hands-on Practice: From coding essentials to advanced techniques, gain practical insights through interactive learning.



4 When is this taught?
Course Link: Course website Dates: May 14th and 15th, 2022
Audience: Members of the Marie Curie Alumni Association - India Chapter
Supported By: The Carpentries
Funded By: Marie Curie Alumni Association
This course combined theoretical foundations with hands-on practice, empowering participants to leverage data visualization for impactful communication and decision-making. Stay tuned for future opportunities to advance your skills in data analysis and visualization with us!

title: Creating Interactive Maps with R: A Beginner’s Guide Using ggplot2 and leaflet
text:
TL;DR



In this tutorial, you’ll learn how to create static maps using ggplot2 and interactive maps using leaflet in R. We’ll cover the basics, provide code examples, and include tips and troubleshooting advice. By the end, you’ll be able to create customized maps to visualize geographic data effectively.
Welcome to this step-by-step tutorial where you’ll learn how to create beautiful and interactive maps using R. We’ll be using two powerful R packages: ggplot2 for static maps and leaflet for interactive maps. Whether you’re a beginner or looking to refine your mapping skills, this guide will walk you through the basics and provide some handy tips and tricks along the way.

title: Creating Interactive Maps with R: A Beginner’s Guide Using ggplot2 and leaflet
text:
3.1 Step 1: Load the Libraries
First, load the required libraries.


Code
1library(ggplot2)
2library(magrittr)
3library(rnaturalearth)
4library(rnaturalearthdata)
5library(sf)



1

Load the ggplot2 package for data visualization.

2

Load the magrittr package for pipe operations.

3

Load the rnaturalearth package to access natural earth map data.

4

Load the rnaturalearthdata package for additional natural earth data.

5

Load the sf package for handling spatial data.

title: Creating Interactive Maps with R: A Beginner’s Guide Using ggplot2 and leaflet
text:
3.2 Step 2: Load the Data
For this tutorial, we’ll use the rnaturalearth package, which provides natural earth vector map data in various scales. We’ll load world map data using this package.


Code
1world_map <- rnaturalearth::ne_countries(scale = "medium", returnclass = "sf")



1

Loads the world map data at a medium scale and returns it as an sf (simple features) object.

title: Creating Interactive Maps with R: A Beginner’s Guide Using ggplot2 and leaflet
text:
3.3 Step 3: Create the Map
We’ll use ggplot2 to plot the world map.


Code
1ggplot_map <- ggplot2::ggplot(world_map) +
2  ggplot2::geom_sf() +
3  ggplot2::theme_minimal() +
4  ggplot2::labs(title = "World Map", x = "Longitude", y = "Latitude") +
  ggplot2::theme(
    panel.grid.major = element_line(color = gray(.5), 
5                                    linetype = "dashed", size = 0.5),
6    panel.background = element_rect(fill = "aliceblue"))
7ggplot_map



1

Create a ggplot object using world_map data.

2

Plot the geographic features using geom_sf.

3

Apply a minimal theme to the plot.

4

Add title and axis labels.

5

Customize the major grid lines.

6

Set the background colour to aliceblue.

7

Display the map.

title: Creating Interactive Maps with R: A Beginner’s Guide Using ggplot2 and leaflet
text:
3.4 Step 4: Save the Map
Once the final map is prepared, it can be conveniently saved in various formats using the ggsave() function. The formats include the widely used PNG (a raster bitmap) and PDF (vector graphics), with the ability to control the size and resolution of the output. In this case, we are saving a PDF version of the map, which maintains the highest quality, and a PNG version for web usage
ggplot2::ggsave("ggplot_map.png", 
       plot= ggplot_map, 
1       width = 6, height = 8, dpi = "screen")
ggplot2::ggsave("ggplot_map.pdf", 
       plot= ggplot_map, 
2       width = 6, height = 8, dpi = 300)

1

Save map as a PNG file with screen resolution.

2

Save map as a PDF file with 300 dpi resolution








ggsave()



If you’re creating a PDF for web use, a dpi of 72 is usually sufficient. If you’re creating a PDF for print, a dpi of 300 or higher is recommended. If you’re not sure what dpi to use, it’s best to check with your printer or the specifications of the website where you plan to upload the PDF.

title: Creating Interactive Maps with R: A Beginner’s Guide Using ggplot2 and leaflet
text:
3.5 Customizing the Static Map

3.5.1 Adding additional layers: An Example with Points
To make your static map more informative and visually appealing, you can add additional layers such as points representing specific locations. Here’s how to do it step-by-step.

3.5.1.1 Step 1: Create a Data Frame with Location Data
First, create a data frame containing the locations you want to plot on the map.


Code
1sites <- data.frame(
2  city = c("Bath","Keynsham", "Bristol", "Chippenham", "Trowbridge"),
3  latitude = c(51.380001, 51.41505900, 51.45451300, 51.45805800, 51.31966400),
4  longitude = c(-2.360000, -2.50252600, -2.58791000, -2.11607390, -2.20885300))
5head(sites)



1

Create a data frame named sites.

2

Define the city column with city names.

3

Define the latitude column with the corresponding latitudes.

4

Define the longitude column with the corresponding longitudes.

5

Display the sites data frame.




        city latitude longitude
1       Bath 51.38000 -2.360000
2   Keynsham 51.41506 -2.502526
3    Bristol 51.45451 -2.587910
4 Chippenham 51.45806 -2.116074
5 Trowbridge 51.31966 -2.208853




3.5.1.2 Step 2: Plot the Map with Additional Layers
Next, use ggplot2 to create a map with the world map data and add points from the sites data frame.


Code
1ggplot_map <- ggplot2::ggplot(world_map) +
2  ggplot2::geom_sf() +
3  ggplot2::geom_point(data = sites, ggplot2::aes(x = longitude, y = latitude), size = 2, shape = 23, fill = "darkred") +
4  ggplot2::theme_minimal() +
5  ggplot2::labs(title = "My Map", x = "Longitude", y = "Latitude") +
6  ggplot2::coord_sf(xlim = c(-3.6, -1.5), ylim = c(50.5, 52), expand = FALSE) +
  ggplot2::theme(
    panel.grid.major = element_line(color = gray(.5), 
7                                    linetype = "dashed", size = 0.5),
8    panel.background = element_rect(fill = "aliceblue"))
9ggplot_map



1

Create a ggplot object using world_map data.

2

Plot the geographic features using geom_sf.

3

Add points from sites data with longitude and latitude, customized size, shape, and fill colour.

4

Apply a minimal theme to the plot.

5

Add title and axis labels.

6

Set the spatial coordinates to focus.

7

Customize the major grid lines.

8

Set the background colour to aliceblue.

9

Display the map.











By following these steps, you can add various layers to your static maps, enhancing the visualization with additional data points and custom styling.

title: Creating Interactive Maps with R: A Beginner’s Guide Using ggplot2 and leaflet
text:
4.1 Step 1: Load the Libraries
Load the leaflet library


Code
1library(leaflet)



1

Load the leaflet package for interactive maps.

title: Creating Interactive Maps with R: A Beginner’s Guide Using ggplot2 and leaflet
text:
4.2 Step 2: Create the Map
We’ll create an interactive map centered on a specific location.


Code
1leaflet_map <- leaflet::leaflet() %>%
2  leaflet::addTiles() %>%
3  leaflet::addMarkers(lng = -0.09, lat = 51.505, popup = "Hello, London!")
4leaflet_map



1

Initialize a leaflet map object.

2

Add default OpenStreetMap tiles to the map.

3

Add a marker at the specified longitude and latitude with a popup message.

4

Display the map.














Explore Different Basemaps



Change the basemap using addProviderTiles() function, e.g., addProviderTiles(providers$Stamen.Toner)

title: Creating Interactive Maps with R: A Beginner’s Guide Using ggplot2 and leaflet
text:
4.3 Step 3: Customize the Map
Let’s add more features, such as multiple markers and custom popups.


Code
1leaflet_map <- leaflet::leaflet() %>%
2  leaflet::addTiles() %>%
3  leaflet::addMarkers(lng = c(-0.09, -0.1), lat = c(51.505, 51.51),
4             popup = c("Hello, London!", "Another Location"))
5leaflet_map



1

Initialize a leaflet map object.

2

Add default OpenStreetMap tiles to the map.

3

Add multiple markers at specified longitudes and latitudes.

4

Add custom popup messages for each marker.

5

Display the map.

title: Creating Interactive Maps with R: A Beginner’s Guide Using ggplot2 and leaflet
text:
5.1 Advanced ggplot2 Features
To enhance your static maps further, you can customize themes, add annotations, and use scale transformations. These advanced features can make your map more informative and visually appealing.


Code
1library(ggspatial)
2library(ggrepel)

3ggplot_map <- ggplot2::ggplot(world_map) +
4  ggplot2::geom_sf() +
5  ggplot2::geom_point(data = sites, ggplot2::aes(x = longitude, y = latitude), size = 2, shape = 23, fill = "darkred") +
  ggrepel::geom_text_repel (data =  sites,
            ggplot2::aes(x = longitude, y = latitude,
                         label= city), 
6            size = 4 ) +
7  ggplot2::theme_minimal() +
8  ggplot2::labs(title = "My Map", x = "Longitude", y = "Latitude") +
9  ggplot2::coord_sf(xlim = c(-3.6, -1.5), ylim = c(50.5, 52), expand = FALSE) +
  ggplot2::theme(
    panel.grid.major = element_line(color = gray(.5), 
10                                    linetype = "dashed", size = 0.5),
11    panel.background = element_rect(fill = "aliceblue")) +
  ggspatial::annotation_north_arrow(
     location = "tl",
     pad_x = unit(0.1, "in"),
     pad_y = unit(0.1, "in"),
     style = ggspatial::north_arrow_fancy_orienteering(
       line_col = "black",
       text_size = 12,
12       text_col = "black")) +
  ggspatial::annotation_scale(
    location = "br",
    width_hint = 0.3,
    text_cex = 0.5,
    pad_x = unit(0.1, "cm"),
13    pad_y = unit(0.1, "cm"))
14ggplot_map



1

Load the ggspatial package for spatial annotations.

2

Load the ggrepel package for repelling text labels.

3

Create a ggplot object using world_map data.

4

Plot the geographic features using geom_sf.

5

Add points from sites data with longitude and latitude, customized size, shape, and fill colour.

6

Add repelled text labels for city names using ggrepel.

7

Apply a minimal theme to the plot.

8

Add title and axis labels.

9

Set the spatial coordinates to focus.

10

Customize the major grid lines.

11

Set the background colour to aliceblue.

12

Add a north arrow annotation at the top left of the plot.

13

Add a scale bar annotation at the bottom right of the plot.

14

Display the map.

title: Creating Interactive Maps with R: A Beginner’s Guide Using ggplot2 and leaflet
text:
5.2 Advanced leaflet Features
For interactive maps, leaflet offers advanced features that allow you to add layers, custom controls, and integrate with other web technologies.






Polygons and Circles



Use addPolygons() and addCircles() to highlight specific areas on your map.




Code
1leaflet_map <- leaflet::leaflet() %>%
2  leaflet::addTiles() %>%
3  leaflet::addMarkers(lng = -0.09, lat = 51.505, popup = "Hello, London!") %>%
4  leaflet::addCircles(lng = -0.1, lat = 51.51, weight = 1, radius = 50,
5             popup = "Circle around another location")
6leaflet_map



1

Initialize a leaflet map object.

2

Add default OpenStreetMap tiles to the map.

3

Add a marker at the specified longitude and latitude with a popup message.

4

Add a circle at the specified longitude and latitude with a specified weight and radius.

5

Add a popup message for the circle.

6

Display the map.








These advanced features in ggplot2 and leaflet enable you to create detailed, informative, and visually appealing maps, whether they are static or interactive. By leveraging these tools, you can effectively communicate geographic data to your audience.






Common Mistakes



When creating maps in R, there are a few common mistakes that can lead to errors or unexpected results. Here are some tips to help you avoid these pitfalls:

Wrong Coordinates: Ensure your longitude and latitude values are correct; otherwise, your markers will not appear where expected.
Missing Libraries: Always load the necessary libraries before running your code.
Incorrect Data Types: Make sure your longitude and latitude columns are numeric. If they are factors or characters, convert them using as.numeric().
Mismatched Coordinate Reference Systems (CRS): Ensure your spatial data and map layers use the same CRS to avoid misalignment.
Overlapping Layers: Be careful with the order of layers in ggplot2. Layers added later will be on top of earlier ones, which might obscure important data.
Improper Aesthetics Mapping: Double-check that the aes() function correctly maps your data columns to aesthetics in ggplot2.
Forgetting to Print the Plot: In scripts or R Markdown documents, ensure you explicitly print the ggplot object to render the plot.
Large Data Sets: For very large spatial data sets, rendering can be slow. Consider simplifying your data or using more efficient packages like sf.
Incorrect File Paths: When loading spatial data from files, ensure the file paths are correct and the files are accessible.
Not Saving Plots: If you want to save your plots, use functions like ggsave() for ggplot2 maps and htmlwidgets::saveWidget() for leaflet maps.









Troubleshooting



When things go wrong, here are some troubleshooting tips to help you diagnose and fix common issues:

Error: Object not found: Ensure all objects (e.g., data frames, variables) are defined in your environment.
Map not displaying: Check your longitude and latitude values and ensure your map container is correctly set up if embedding in a Shiny app or R Markdown document.
Incorrect CRS: If your spatial data doesn’t align, check and transform CRS using functions like st_transform() from the sf package.
Slow Performance: If rendering is slow, consider reducing the complexity of your spatial data, using faster algorithms, or rendering smaller sections of the map.
Layer Ordering Issues: If some layers are hidden, reorder your ggplot2 layers to ensure that important data is not obscured.
Library Conflicts: Sometimes, functions from different libraries can conflict. Ensure you are calling functions with the correct namespace (e.g., ggplot2::geom_point()).
Missing Data: Check for NA values in your data, especially in critical columns like longitude and latitude. Handle missing data appropriately.
Plot Size: If your plot appears squished or improperly scaled, adjust the plot dimensions using ggsave() or fig.width and fig.height in R Markdown.
Browser Compatibility: For leaflet maps, ensure you are using a compatible web browser, and try refreshing the page if the map does not load.
Dependency Issues: Make sure all necessary packages and their dependencies are installed and up to date. Use install.packages() to install missing packages.
Resource Limits: For interactive maps, ensure your system has sufficient resources (memory, processing power) to handle large datasets and complex visualizations.

title: PrAna
text:
Project Page    Source Code 
Introducing PrAna: A Powerful Tool for Analysing England’s NHS Primary Care Prescribing Data
In the realm of healthcare and environmental science, understanding the consumption of active pharmaceutical ingredients (APIs) is crucial. PrAna emerges as a ground breaking tool that brings a new dimension to the analysis of England’s NHS primary care prescribing data.
Developed as an R package, PrAna is designed to aggregate and normalize England’s national level prescription data. It calculates the total prescribed quantity of different APIs, using open source statistical software R language. This data is vital for predicting the total amount of APIs released into the environment.
PrAna is complemented by a user-friendly interactive tool, PrAnaViz, developed using the R/Shiny framework. This tool allows users to explore and visualize the spatio-temporal trends of the total prescribed quantity of APIs. Users can also download the results in various data formats for their further studies.
With PrAna and PrAnaViz, users can visualize, explore, and report different spatio-temporal and long-term prescription trends for wider use. This can be used as a support tool for policy-makers, academics, researchers in public healthcare, and environmental scientists to monitor different groups of pharmaceuticals emitted to the environment and for prospective risk assessment of pharmaceuticals in the environment.
Published in the esteemed journal BMC Medical Informatics and Decision Making(Jagadeesan et al. 2022), PrAna is a significant contribution to the field, empowering researchers to efficiently handle and interpret complex prescription data.
Explore the Features of PrAna
PrAna is packed with features that make it a versatile tool for any researcher working with England’s NHS primary care prescribing data:

Data Aggregation and Normalization: Transform your complex prescription datasets into easy-to-understand formats.
API Consumption Calculation: Calculate the total prescribed quantity of different APIs, vital for predicting the total amount of APIs released into the environment.
Interactive Visualization: Explore and visualize the spatio-temporal trends of the total prescribed quantity of APIs with PrAnaViz.
Data Export: Download the results in various data formats for your further studies.
Accessibility: Access PrAna from any operating system without the need for local installation.

With PrAna, navigating through the complexities of England’s NHS primary care prescribing data has never been easier.




References

Jagadeesan, Kishore Kumar, James Grant, Sue Griffin, Ruth Barden, and Barbara Kasprzyk-Hordern. 2022. “PrAna: An R Package to Calculate and Visualize England NHS Primary Care Prescribing Data.” BMC Medical Informatics and Decision Making 22 (1). https://doi.org/10.1186/s12911-021-01727-z.

title: Kishore Kumar Jagadeesan
text: Hello! I’m Kishore Kumar Jagadeesan, a Research Associate with a passion for environmental science, water quality, and public health. Currently, I’m @ the University of Bath , where I excel in creating research tools for statistical analysis and data visualization across diverse disciplines. Feel free to explore my website to learn more!

title: About Me
text:
Hello! I’m Kishore Jagadeesan, a Postdoctoral Research Associate at the Department of Chemistry, University of Bath, UK. I’m passionate about the environment, water quality, and public health.
My work primarily involves developing research tools for statistical analysis and visualization of massive datasets across many disciplines. I’m highly proficient in coding with R and HTML. One of my notable contributions is the development of PERK, an R/Shiny application tool that predicts and visualizes environmental concentration and risk using pharmaceutical prescription data collected at fine spatial resolution.
I’m always excited to connect with others who share similar interests. I’m also open to discussions about R Shiny, mass spectrometry, data visualization, and wastewater epidemiology.
For more information on my past work and contributions, feel free to explore my website and my GitHub profile. Thank you for visiting!

title: MALDIViz
text:
Shiny Dashboard 
MALDIViz: A Comprehensive Informatics Tool for MALDI-MS Data Visualization and Analysis
MALDIViz is a comprehensive informatics tool designed to address the challenges posed by the large datasets generated by high-throughput screening (HTS) using matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization mass spectrometry (MALDI-MS). This technique is widely used in HTS due to its low cost, speed, and automation capabilities.
The complexity of the experimental data, such as screening many different sorbent phases, the sorbent mass, and the load, wash, and elution conditions, makes manual data analysis difficult. To overcome these challenges, MALDIViz was developed.
MALDIViz is an R-Shiny-based web application, accessible independently of the operating system and without the need to install any program locally. It has been designed to facilitate easy analysis and visualization of MALDI-MS datasets, comparison of multiplex experiments, and export of the analysis results to high-quality images.
Key Features:

Data Visualization: MALDIViz provides a robust platform for visualizing complex MALDI-MS datasets. This feature allows users to gain insights from their data in a graphical format, making it easier to interpret and understand the results.
Statistical Analysis: The tool includes built-in functions for performing statistical analysis on the data. This can help users identify significant patterns and trends in their datasets.
Comparison of Multiplex Experiments: MALDIViz allows users to compare results from multiple experiments. This can be particularly useful when trying to understand the effects of different variables on the results.
High-Quality Image and Data Export: Users can export the analysis results as high-quality images¹. This feature makes it easy to share the results with others or use them in presentations and reports.
Accessibility: MALDIViz is an R-Shiny-based web application, which means it can be accessed independently of the operating system and without the need to install any program locally.




MALDIViz: Workflow and Features


These features make MALDIViz a versatile and powerful tool for researchers working with MALDI-MS data. It was published in the journal SLAS DISCOVERY: Advancing Life Sciences R&D(Jagadeesan and Ekström 2017)¹.




References

Jagadeesan, Kishore Kumar, and Simon Ekström. 2017. “MALDIViz: A Comprehensive Informatics Tool for MALDI-MS Data Visualization and Analysis.” SLAS Discovery 22 (10): 1246–52. https://doi.org/10.1177/2472555217727517.

title: PERK
text:
Project Page    Source Code 
PERK, an acronym for Predicting Environmental concentration and RisK, is an R/Shiny application tool. It is designed to facilitate automated modelling and reporting of predicted environmental concentrations of a comprehensive set of pharmaceuticals derived from a wide range of therapeutic classes with different modes of action.
The tool allows users to input their measured concentration, and compare the predicted (PEC) and measured concentrations (MEC) of the pharmaceuticals by means of the PEC/MEC ratio. This helps to establish whether the predicted equations used tend to underestimate or overestimate measured values.
PERK provides a consistent interactive user interface in a familiar dashboard layout, enabling users to visualize predicted values and compare them with their measured values without any hassles¹². Users can download data and graphs generated using the tool in .csv format or as publication-ready images.
The tool uses prescription data from PrAna, an R package to calculate and visualize England NHS prescribing data. It also uses data from WWTP collaborators, API properties, recovery percentage, physio-chemical properties, and eco-toxicity data collected from research articles and data repositories.
PERK is easy to install and use. With just a few commands, users can install it and begin using it. For an introduction to the package, step-by-step instructions on getting started, and more information on the different ways you can use the package, users can refer to the PERK-Walkthrough tutorial.
This work is a part of the Wastewater Fingerprinting for Public Health Assessment (ENTRUST) project funded by Wessex Water and EPSRC IAA (grant no. EP/R51164X/1). If the package helps you with your work in any way that justifies it, please cite the article published in Science of The Total Environment(Jagadeesan, Barden, and Kasprzyk-Hordern 2023).




References

Jagadeesan, Kishore Kumar, Ruth Barden, and Barbara Kasprzyk-Hordern. 2023. “PERK: An R/Shiny Application to Predict and Visualise Concentrations of Pharmaceuticals in the Aqueous Environment.” Science of The Total Environment 875 (June): 162352. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.scitotenv.2023.162352.

text:
0.0.1 2022

0.0.2 2021

title: NHS-R Webinar: August 2022
text:
1 Webinar: PrAna - R package to calculate & visualize NHS primary care prescribing data
I’m delighted to share with you a talk (Webinar) I recently gave on Wednesday, 17th August 2022. The talk, now available for viewing on YouTube, is centred around PrAna, an R package that has significantly transformed the way we analyse England NHS primary care prescribing data.
PrAna is an R package that calculates and visualizes England NHS prescribing data. It’s a tool that has been instrumental in my work, particularly in the development of the PERK tool, which predicts and visualizes environmental concentration and risk using pharmaceutical prescription data collected at fine spatial resolution.
In the talk, I discuss the inspiration behind PrAna, the challenges we faced during its development, and how it has transformed the way we understand and interpret complex datasets. I also share some real-world applications of PrAna, demonstrating its versatility and power in tackling a wide range of research questions.
The talk concludes with a Q&A session, where I answer questions from the audience about PrAna, its applications, and future developments.
This talk was organized by the NHS-R Community, a vibrant community that regularly hosts webinars and workshops on a wide range of topics related to R programming and healthcare data analysis. Their events provide a platform for sharing knowledge, learning new skills, and networking with other professionals in the field
Whether you’re a data scientist, a researcher, or simply someone interested in data analysis, I believe you’ll find this talk both informative and inspiring.
Check out the full presentation on YouTube and feel free to share your thoughts and questions in the comments section. I look forward to hearing your feedback!

Stay tuned for more updates and talks in the future. Thank you for your continued support and interest in my work!
